metadata.case_name: Bombay Port Trust v. New Great Insurance Co.

facts.text: Consignment of 53 bundles of mild steel plates despatched by Japanese exporter to be delivered at Bombay port.
Goods discharged into custody of Bombay Port Trust on September 12, 1959.
Goods insured; second plaintiff is the insurer who subrogated to first plaintiff's rights after payment.
Delivery applied for and given on September 19, 1959, but only 52 bundles delivered; one bundle missing.
First plaintiff demanded missing bundle; Port Trust letters on September 29, October 10, and December 4, 1959 assuring search in progress.
Plaintiffs' letter September 26, 1959 sought information on whereabouts of missing bundle.
Inquiry to Indian Maritime Enterprises (agents of vessel); reply November 7, 1959 confirmed all 53 bundles duly unloaded.
Plaintiffs' letter December 5, 1959 to Port Trust noting agents' confirmation of landing and seeking confirmation of landing or short landing.
Port Trust informed on January 22, 1960 that bundle out-turned as landed but missing.
Statutory notice under S.87 issued May 12, 1960.
Suit filed June 18, 1960 in Court of Small Causes for value of missing bundle.
Small Causes Court held defendant negligent, repelled limitation plea, decreed for plaintiffs.
Full Court in appeal set aside decree holding claim barred by limitation under Act.
High Court single Judge upset limitation finding, directed disposal on merits.
Appeal by special leave to Supreme Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether suit for short delivery is for 'any thing done, or purporting to have been done, in pursuance of this Act' under S.87 Bombay Port Trust Act, 1879, attracting 6-month limitation.

When does the cause of action accrue and limitation begin to run under S.87 - from date of short delivery around a week after landing (S.61A), or when owner finally refused delivery or knew of landing and loss.

petitioner_arguments.text: Act includes omission; non-delivery is part of statutory duty to accept, store, and deliver goods; done in pursuance of Act.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: S.87 Bombay Port Trust Act; precedents like Jolliffe v. Wallasey Local Board

petitioner_arguments.text: Limitation runs from reasonable time after landing when goods ought to be delivered; bulk delivery on Sept 19, 1959 starts clock; search letters do not postpone.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: S.61A, S.87 Bombay Port Trust Act; Bootamal v. Union of India

petitioner_arguments.text: Knowledge of landing not required for cause; presumed from bulk delivery; suit barred beyond 6 months + notice.

respondent_arguments.text: Omission/non-delivery not 'act done or purporting to be done in pursuance of Act'; violation of duty, not pursuant to Act.
Cause accrues only when plaintiff has knowledge of landing and loss; earliest clear knowledge Nov 7, 1959 or later.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Art.120 Limitation Act analogy; scienter required for cause

respondent_arguments.text: Limitation Act longer period applies, not short S.87.

court_reasoning.text: Act includes omission where part of course of conduct under statute; non-delivery in discharge of bailee duty under S.61B is 'purporting to be done in pursuance of Act'.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Omission has activist facet; complex of act-omission in official duty covered; precedents support.

court_reasoning.text: S.87 applies to protect public body; short limitation for fresh evidence.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Protective purpose for Port Trust as statutory bailee.

court_reasoning.text: Cause accrues when consignee knows goods landed into port custody (bailment starts); reasonable time for delivery after.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Knowledge of bailment essential; not from final refusal.

court_reasoning.text: Bulk delivery date (Sept 19) or 7 days post-landing indicates knowledge; search letters post-knowledge do not postpone limitation.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Nov 7, 1959 knowledge from agents; suit June 18, 1960 barred by 6 months +1 month notice.

court_reasoning.text: Plaintiff knew of landing by Nov 7, 1959; subsequent correspondence for documents, not new knowledge.

holdings.text: S.87 Bombay Port Trust Act applies to suit for short delivery as omission in course of statutory duty.
Limitation under S.87 (6 months +1 month notice) runs from when consignee knows of landing; bulk delivery date presumptive.

precedents_cited.relevance: Omission to complete duty is act done under statute for limitation/notice.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner for the Port of Calcutta v. Corporation of Calcutta
precedents_cited.relevance: Purporting to act covers work professing to be under statute.
Limitation from reasonable time for delivery, not final refusal; tracing irrelevant.
Non-compliance/omission is thing done under Act.
Act within scope of official duty if reasonably claimable under office.

precedents_cited.case_name: Hori Ram Singh v. The Crown
precedents_cited.relevance: Conduct as whole, including omissions, in execution of duty.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Gujarat v. Kansara Manilal Bhikhala
precedents_cited.relevance: Protection only for compliance/intended compliance, not breach; different context.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Port Trust Act, 1879
statutes_cited.relevance: Short limitation/notice for suits re acts/omissions in pursuance; bailee duty; 7-day removal period.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Contract Act, 1872
statutes_cited.relevance: Bailee's duty of care, liability for non-delivery.

statutes_cited.name: Limitation Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Tacking notice period; analogy for accrual on knowledge.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; suit held barred by limitation under S.87 Bombay Port Trust Act as filed beyond 6 months from November 7, 1959 when plaintiffs knew of landing.

key_quotes.text: Non-delivery of an article is an omission, not an act and, in any case, not one in pursuance of the Act, because the statute does not direct the Port Trust not to deliver the goods.
key_quotes.speaker: respondent
key_quotes.significance: Respondent's key argument rejected by court.

key_quotes.text: An omission to do something which ought to be done in order to completely perform the duty... amounts to an act done or intended to be done.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on act including omission, citing Halsbury and precedents.

key_quotes.text: The cause of action for short delivery comes into being only when the consignee comes to know that the bailment has come into existence.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The suit was instituted on June 18, 1960, a little over 10 days beyond the period of limitation. The plaintiffs thus missed the bus.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Final determination on bar of limitation.
